newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Diana arrives in Bosnia to crusade against mines.
newsitem.headline: Diana arrives in Bosnia to crusade against mines.

text.p: Britain's Princess Diana arrived in the battle-scarred Bosnian capital of Sarajevo on Friday to crusade against landmines.

The divorced princess, trying to forge a role as a roving humanitarian ambassador, planned to visit victims of mines and to meet rehabilitation specialists on a three-day trip to a country still recovering from a devastating war.

Diana's white private Lear jet touched down shortly after midday as a gaggle of press waited on the tarmac of Sarajevo Airport, once the scene of vicious fighting between rival armies during the Bosnian war.
Diana, dressed in trousers, blue blazer and light blue shirt, looking fit and tanned, shook hands with the British Ambassador and got in a van headed for the central town of Tuzla.

On the morning of her departure, British tabloids were full of speculation about Diana's friendship with divorced, polo-playing film producer Dodi Fayed, 41, and said the divorced princess had been seen entering his luxury London apartment for a dinner date.
The Daily Mail's front page headline read: "Diana - it's a real romance", while The Sun said: "Romantic meal in new love's London flat -- then farewell kiss before Bosnia".
Her 15-year marriage to British royal heir Prince Charles ended in divorce last year.
Diana, 36, was invited to Sarajevo on a "private visit" by the Washington-based Landmine Survivors' Network to highlight the plight of victims of landmines.
The Foreign Office earlier gave its clearance for the trip to go ahead, despite security concerns.
